questions.prompt: What does 'direct coupling' mean in a multi-stage amplifier?
options: The stages are connected using a transformer
The collector of one stage is connected directly to the base of the next without a coupling capacitor
Both transistors share the same base terminal
The stages are connected using an operational amplifier
questions.correctAnswer: The collector of one stage is connected directly to the base of the next without a coupling capacitor
questions.explanation: Direct coupling means no capacitor between stages — the DC collector voltage of Stage 1 serves directly as the base bias voltage of Stage 2. This eliminates low-frequency rolloff caused by coupling capacitors.

questions.prompt: Which transistor combination is used in this lab's two-stage amplifier?
options: NPN first stage (BC549) + PNP second stage (BC556)
PNP first stage (BC556) + NPN second stage (BC549)
questions.correctAnswer: NPN first stage (BC549) + PNP second stage (BC556)
questions.explanation: The first stage uses an NPN BC549 and the second stage uses a PNP BC556. This complementary arrangement provides thermal stability because the temperature drifts of the two transistor types partially cancel each other.

questions.prompt: What is the primary frequency response advantage of direct coupling over capacitor coupling?
options: Gain is maintained down to DC (no low-frequency cutoff)
questions.correctAnswer: Gain is maintained down to DC (no low-frequency cutoff)
questions.explanation: A coupling capacitor acts as a high-pass filter — at low frequencies, its impedance (1/ωC) becomes large and reduces gain. Direct coupling eliminates this effect, maintaining gain all the way down to DC.

questions.prompt: Why does the NPN-PNP combination provide better thermal stability than NPN-NPN?
options: PNP transistors are immune to temperature changes
The temperature drifts of NPN and PNP partially cancel each other
NPN-PNP uses less power, generating less heat
PNP transistors have higher thermal resistance cases
questions.correctAnswer: The temperature drifts of NPN and PNP partially cancel each other
questions.explanation: When temperature rises, IC1 increases and VC1 decreases. Since VC1 = VB2 (direct coupling), this lower VB2 causes IC2 in the PNP to decrease. The opposing directions create inherent negative feedback that partially cancels the drift.

questions.prompt: In the direct-coupled amplifier, VB2 (base voltage of Q2) is equal to:
questions.explanation: This is the key relationship in direct coupling. The collector of Q1 connects directly to the base of Q2, so VC1 = VB2. Any change in IC1 (through R1) changes VC1, which directly changes the bias of Q2.

questions.prompt: The E12 resistor series provides how many values per decade?
questions.explanation: E12 provides 12 standard values per decade: 1.0, 1.2, 1.5, 1.8, 2.2, 2.7, 3.3, 3.9, 4.7, 5.6, 6.8, 8.2. Each can be multiplied by powers of 10 (e.g., 220Ω, 2.2kΩ, 22kΩ are all E12 values).

questions.prompt: If your calculation gives R = 140Ω, what E12 value should you select?
questions.explanation: 150Ω is the nearest E12 value to 140Ω (E12 values: ...120, 150, 180...). Custom values are not available in standard resistor kits. 120Ω would also work but introduces more error. The designer chooses based on which direction of error is more acceptable.

questions.prompt: The h-parameter hoe = 18μS for the BC549 corresponds to an output resistance of approximately:
questions.explanation: hoe is the output admittance in siemens. The output resistance is 1/hoe = 1/(18 × 10⁻⁶) ≈ 55,600Ω ≈ 56 kΩ. Since this is much larger than typical collector/emitter resistors (1-5 kΩ), we can often ignore hoe in our analysis.

questions.prompt: How many separate bias circuits are needed for the two-stage direct-coupled amplifier?
options: One — the Ra/Rb divider biases both stages
Three — one for each stage plus the interstage
questions.correctAnswer: One — the Ra/Rb divider biases both stages
questions.explanation: This is the elegance of direct coupling: a single voltage divider (Ra, Rb) at the input sets VB1, which determines IC1, which determines VC1 = VB2, which determines IC2. One bias network controls everything.

questions.prompt: When engineers make the approximation 'the effect of the larger parallel resistor can be ignored if it is 10× the smaller one,' this is called:
questions.explanation: When two resistors are in parallel and one is 10× larger, the parallel combination is within 10% of the smaller resistor. Engineers accept this error to simplify analysis. For example, if R1 = 10kΩ and R2 = 100kΩ, then R1 ∥ R2 ≈ 9.1kΩ ≈ R1.

questions.prompt: What is the maximum continuous power dissipation of the BC549 transistor?
questions.explanation: From the datasheet, the maximum power dissipation at Ta = 25°C is 500 mW. This is calculated as P = VCE × IC, and the designer must ensure the operating point stays below this limit at all times.
